parts:
Below is DBS’ **current** (publicly stated) process and requirements for a **Singapore sole proprietorship** opening a business/corporate account (typically via **DBS SME Banking**, e.g. the DBS Business Multi-Currency Account). citeturn7view0turn8view0

## 1) Procedure (what you actually do)
1) **Pick the account variant**
- If your business is **< 3 years old**: DBS markets the **DBS Business Multi-Currency Account – Starter Bundle** (S$10 monthly account fee; no monthly service charge). citeturn12view0  
- If your business is **≥ 3 years old**: DBS markets the **DBS Business Multi-Currency Account** (annual account fee + monthly service charge unless you keep the required average balance). citeturn7view0turn6view0  

2) **Prepare key details**
- DBS says to have your **UEN (Unique Entity Number)** and the **contact details of all account users** ready (e.g., authorised signers and DBS IDEAL users). citeturn7view0turn12view0  

3) **Apply online**
- DBS’ flow is: get ready → complete the online application → DBS emails your account access info after successful application. citeturn7view0turn12view0  
- If you can’t find your entity during the “ACRA Details” step, DBS suggests trying your name without suffixes; for newly registered entities, DBS notes it can take **2 working days** for details to be retrievable via ACRA search. citeturn7view0turn12view0  

4) **If you’re not eligible for “instant opening”**
- DBS says Singapore-incorporated entities fully owned by Singapore citizens/PRs **may not need** to submit documents, but **some businesses will be asked for additional documents** per DBS’ checklist (and DBS will contact you). citeturn7view0turn12view0  

---

## 2) Documentation you may be asked for (sole proprietor)
From DBS’ **Account Opening Checklist** for *Sole Proprietor* (documents to bring if a visit is required): citeturn8view0  

- **Original ID** (NRIC / Passport + FIN where applicable) of:
  - the **sole proprietor**, and  
  - all **authorised signatories**, **DBS IDEAL** approvers/admins, and any **power of attorney (POA)** holders. citeturn8view0  
- **FATCA & CRS form** (Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act / Common Reporting Standard) — to be signed by the **sole proprietor**. citeturn8view0  
- **Proof of residential address** for relevant persons (examples listed by DBS include NRIC / utility bill / bank statement / government correspondence; DBS’ examples specify **dated within last 3 months**). citeturn8view0  
- **Proof of principal place of business** (only if different from the registered business address). citeturn8view0  
- **Certified true copy** of a **resolution/minutes** for the **sole proprietor** (authorising account opening / mandates). citeturn8view0  
- **Who must show up (if a visit is required):** DBS states the **sole proprietor must be present** with original ID. citeturn8view0  

DBS also states: **documents must be in English** and it **may request additional documents** depending on the setup. citeturn8view0  

---

## 3) Minimum deposit, minimum balance, and common fees (DBS-stated)
### DBS Business Multi-Currency Account (standard; typically ≥ 3 years in business)
DBS states (on its SME pages):
- **Minimum initial deposit:** **S$1,000** citeturn6view0  
- **Minimum average balance (to avoid fall-below/service charge):** **S$10,000** citeturn6view0turn7view0  
- **Fall-below / monthly service charge:** **S$40** (waived if the average daily balance is at least S$10,000 or equivalent). citeturn6view0turn7view0  
- **Account service / account fee:** **S$50 per year** (DBS presents this as an annual fee on its pages). citeturn6view0turn7view0  

**Important nuance for multi-currency:** DBS’ pricing guide notes the minimum average daily balance for multi-currency accounts is determined based on **aggregated balances across all wallets** in the account. citeturn4view2  

### DBS Business Multi-Currency Account – Starter Bundle (typically < 3 years in business)
DBS states:
- **Account fee:** **S$10 monthly**  
- **Monthly service charge:** **S$0** citeturn12view0  
DBS also flags higher **over-the-counter** charges for Starter Bundle (see below). citeturn12view0turn7view0  

### Over-the-counter (OTC) transactions
DBS states:
- Standard Business Multi-Currency Account: **S$20 per OTC transaction** citeturn7view0  
- Starter Bundle: **S$40 per OTC transaction** citeturn7view0turn12view0  

### Early account closure fee
DBS pricing guide lists an **Account Closure Fee** of **S$50** if the account is closed **within 6 months** from date of opening. citeturn15view1  

---

## 4) Other rules/regulatory points worth knowing
- **Tax self-certification is not optional:** DBS explicitly requires the **FATCA & CRS** form for account opening checks (this is part of bank compliance). citeturn8view0  
- **Deposit Insurance (Singapore Deposit Insurance Corporation):** SGD deposits are insured **up to S$100,000 per depositor per Scheme member bank**; foreign currency deposits are not insured. citeturn10search2turn10search10  
  - SDIC also states that if you are a **sole proprietor**, insured deposits in your personal name are **aggregated** with insured deposits in the name of your **sole proprietorship** (for coverage calculation). citeturn10search4  
- **If there are foreign beneficial owners / “foreign beneficiaries”:** DBS indicates a different application route and that additional documents may be required. citeturn7view0  

---

If you tell me **(a)** how long your sole prop has been registered (<3 years vs ≥3 years) and **(b)** whether any owners/signers are **non-Singaporean/PR**, I can point you to the most fitting DBS account variant and the *most likely* documentation path (instant vs checklist).

thoughts.summary: Step-by-step procedure for DBS Business Multi-Currency Account
thoughts.content:
1. Ensure your ACRA entity details are correct and accessible.  
2. Have your UEN ready.  
3. Gather contact details.  
4. Apply online.  
5. Make the initial deposit of $1,000.  
6. Maintain an average daily balance of $10k to waive the $40 monthly service charge.  
7. Annual account fee is $50.  

For savings, branch transactions cost $20 each, but cash deposit machines and digital transfers are free. Cheque book fees apply—check the pricing guide for details. 

Additionally, remember to have your NRIC and proof of address ready.

thoughts.summary: Crafting response with details for sole proprietors
thoughts.content: For a sole proprietor with more than three years in business, the appropriate DBS product is the DBS Business Multi-Currency Account (not the Starter). The account has an annual fee of S$50 and a monthly service charge of S$40, waived if your balance exceeds S$10,000. Consider providing details like initial deposit, transaction fees, and service charges clearly. Confirm that the application process is online with UEN and contact details, and that documents may not be needed upfront. Remember that application hours are between 6am-11pm for instant account and IDEAL access.

If visiting the branch, you'll need to be present. The guidelines include regulations like KYC/AML requirements, deposit insurance for up to $100k, and potential additional documents. thoughts.content: For the Business Multi-Currency Account, the usual minimum initial deposit is S$1,000, but it's waived for the first year. There's no formal minimum balance, though a service charge applies if the average daily balance (ADB) falls below S$10,000. An annual account fee of S$50 is separate.

thoughts.summary: Clarifying options for corporate accounts
thoughts.content:
For SMEs, the standard DBS account is the "Business Multi-Currency Account," supporting multiple currencies, including SGD. If you mostly transact in SGD and prefer lower fees, an SGD current account might suit you better, but we won't dive into deep comparisons here. 

For cheques, a chequebook costs $25, though the first book is free. Cash deposits are free at machines, but branch deposits might incur fees beyond certain thresholds.

thoughts.summary: DBS business account opening for a long-standing sole proprietorship (SG citizen, sole signatory)
thoughts.content:
- A separate bank account does not shield personal liability for sole proprietors, despite the product page claiming "liability protection."
- DBS refers to businesses as "companies," but a sole proprietor is a business entity, which may cause some confusion.
- Online onboarding may still work for you — verify if the portal supports sole proprietors, otherwise follow the branch checklist.

thoughts.summary: DBS business account opening for a long-standing sole proprietorship (SG citizen, sole signatory)
thoughts.content:
1. **Best fit account and typical costs: Business Multi-Currency Account (≥3 years), fees and balances**

parts:
Given your facts (**sole proprietorship >10 years**, **Singapore citizen**, **you’re the only signatory**), you’ll normally be routed to DBS’ **DBS Business Multi-Currency Account** (the “> 3 years” tier). citeturn1view0

## 1) What you’ll open (and what it costs)
**DBS Business Multi-Currency Account (for >3 years in business):**
- **Account fee:** **S$50/year** citeturn1view0  
- **Monthly service charge (fall-below):** **S$40/month**, **waived** if **average daily balance ≥ S$10,000 (or equivalent)** citeturn1view0turn2view0  
- **Minimum initial deposit:** **usual S$1,000** citeturn4view0turn4view1  
- **Over-the-counter (branch) transactions:** **S$20 per transaction** (DBS explicitly encourages doing things digitally / via cash deposit machines to save costs) citeturn1view0turn10view0  
- **Account closure fee (if closed < 6 months from opening):** **S$50** citeturn12view0  

**Cheques (only if you need them):**
- **Chequebook:** **S$25/book** (DBS states first book fee is waived for Business Multi-Currency Account) citeturn10view0  
- **Cheque clearing/deposit fees:** DBS lists different fees for Starter vs “all other accounts”; for non-Starter, SGD cheque fees shown are **S$0.75 per cheque** (Starter has higher clearing fees). citeturn10view0  

## 2) Procedure (practical steps)
1) **Get your basics ready**: your **UEN** and your **contact details** (mobile/email). DBS explicitly says to have UEN + contact details of account users on hand. citeturn1view0  
2) **Apply online**: DBS positions this as a fully online application for eligible SG entities; you can save a draft and complete later. citeturn1view0  
3) **Expect “no-document” onboarding most of the time — but be ready**: DBS says **Singapore-owned** entities **may not need to submit documents**, but **some businesses will be asked for additional documents per the checklist** (and DBS will contact you). citeturn1view0  
4) **Timing if you want “instant” setup**: DBS states that for **online account opening**, your business account and DBS IDEAL access are opened **instantly** for submissions between **6am–11pm**. citeturn8view0  
5) **Fund and maintain balances**: transfer in the **initial deposit (usual S$1,000)** and decide whether you’ll keep **≥ S$10,000 average daily balance** to avoid the **S$40/month** service charge. citeturn4view0turn2view0  

## 3) Documents you should prepare (even if online opening doesn’t ask)
DBS’ **Sole Proprietor** checklist (for cases where a visit / documents are required) includes: citeturn11view0  
- **Original NRIC** (you, as sole proprietor) citeturn11view0  
- **FATCA & CRS self-certification** — **signed by the sole proprietor** citeturn11view0  
- **Proof of residential address** (examples given; **dated within last 3 months**) citeturn11view0  
- **Proof of principal place of business** **if different** from registered address citeturn11view0  
- **Certified true copy of resolution / minutes (sole proprietor)** authorising account opening/mandate citeturn11view0  
- **If a visit is needed:** DBS states the **sole proprietor must be present** with original ID. citeturn11view0  

## 4) Other rules / “gotchas” worth knowing
- **Deposit insurance (Singapore):** SDIC insures **Singapore-dollar deposits up to S$100,000 per depositor per scheme member bank**; and **if you are a sole proprietor, deposits in your own name are aggregated with deposits in the sole proprietorship name** (for insurance calculation). citeturn5search4  
- **Single-person control risk:** DBS publishes a **Risk Disclosure Statement for the Application of Single Control** (relevant when only one person can approve/admin changes). citeturn15view0  
  - DBS also explicitly recommends having **at least two DBS IDEAL administrators** for safer change approval (you may choose to ignore this because you operate solo, but understand it increases operational/fraud risk). citeturn16view0  
- **Cash handling charges can kick in at branches:** cash acceptance machines are **waived**, but DBS lists thresholds and fees for branch deposits / cash deposit bags etc. citeturn10view0  
- **PayNow pricing can be promotional/time-bounded:** DBS’ pricing guide shows an “outward PayNow lookup waived till 31 Dec 2025” note—so in **2026** you should treat PayNow lookups/fees as “verify at point of application / latest guide”. citeturn10view0turn12view0  
- **Important reality check (legal):** a “business account” helps accounting and professionalism, but it **does not give you limited liability** as a sole proprietor (your personal liability position is unchanged).

## Quick “do this now” checklist
- ✅ UEN + registered business details (ACRA)  
- ✅ NRIC + address proof (≤3 months)  
- ✅ Be ready to sign **FATCA/CRS** + a **sole proprietor resolution/minutes** citeturn11view0  
- ✅ Plan funding: **S$1,000 initial**; decide whether you’ll park **S$10,000 ADB** to avoid the **S$40/month** charge citeturn4view0turn2view0  
- ✅ Apply online during **6am–11pm** if you want the best chance of “instant” setup citeturn8view0  

If you tell me whether you **need cheques** (some landlords still insist) and whether you expect **regular cash deposits**, I can point out which fees in DBS’ pricing guide are most likely to hit you and how to structure deposits/transfers to minimise them.

thoughts.summary: Providing steps for FATCA/CRS and address mismatch
thoughts.content: When applying online with DBS, you’ll be prompted to complete FATCA/CRS self-certification forms, or you can download them from their website. For address mismatch, DBS needs proof of residential address from documents issued within 3 months. If the address differs from your NRIC, you may need to update it with ICA, though it’s not mandatory.

thoughts.summary: Clarifying address requirements and principal place of business
thoughts.content: DBS requires proof of residential address; if your NRIC address is outdated, alternative documents like utility bills or government letters can be used. thoughts.summary: Creating certified true copy of resolution/minutes
thoughts.content: To create a certified true copy of a resolution/minutes, first draft the "Sole Proprietor's Written Resolution" with necessary details (business name, UEN, date, resolution, etc.). Sign it, keep the original, and make a photocopy. Write "Certified true copy" on each page, then sign, date, and include your NRIC. If required, certification may be done by a DBS branch officer or a notary. I’ll verify DBS’s guidelines.

parts:
## 1) How to obtain the FATCA & CRS self-certification
For a **sole proprietorship owned by an individual**, DBS’ **entity** FATCA/CRS form explicitly says you should use the **individual** self-certification form instead. citeturn1view1

In practice you have two routes:

**A) During DBS’ online business account application**
- DBS’ **account opening checklist** flags a “FATCA & CRS Form … to be signed by … Sole Proprietor” (so you’ll either complete it in-flow or be prompted to upload/submit it). citeturn1view0

**B) Download and complete the DBS individual self-cert form**
- DBS provides a “Self Certification on Tax Residency Status” (individual) PDF. It includes submission options: an online link shown on the form, **mail-in**, or **visit any POSB/DBS branch with your NRIC/Passport for verification**. citeturn8view0  
- The same form also states you should provide a **copy of a government-issued document** to support your tax residence info (e.g., identity card/passport/tax authority document). citeturn8view0

## 2) Can your residential address differ from the address on your NRIC?
**DBS: yes, as long as your proof-of-address matches what you put on the application.**

DBS’ document guidance accepts **telecommunication bills** (and other documents) as proof of residential address, and says:
- **Name and address should match your application form**, and  
- the document must be **dated within 3 months**. citeturn4search12  

DBS’ business account opening checklist similarly lists acceptable proofs (e.g., utility/phone bill, bank statement, government correspondence) **dated within last 3 months**. citeturn1view0

**But you should treat this as a KYC risk if your NRIC address is stale.**  
Singapore rules require NRIC holders to **report a change of address within 28 days**. citeturn7search5 If you haven’t updated it, do it—banks can (and sometimes do) stall applications when core IDs don’t align.

If you want the cleanest path: update your NRIC address via ICA’s e-service (Singpass → submit → PIN mailer to new address → address sticker mailed). citeturn7search0

## 3) Your principal place of business is your current home (not your NRIC address)
DBS’ checklist requires **“Original Proof of Principal Place of Business” if it differs from the business registered address**, and defines principal place of business as where “mind and management” / senior management is located. citeturn1view0

So if you operate from your current home:
- Put that **current home address** as your “principal place of business” (if DBS asks), and  
- be ready with **original proof** for that address (DBS doesn’t hard-list the exact document types here, but it commonly aligns with the same class of documents they accept for address proof). citeturn1view0

Also: if ACRA’s records for you/your business still reflect old addresses, that mismatch can trigger extra questions. ACRA states changes (including **residential address** for business owners/authorised reps) must be updated in BizFile **within 14 days**, and late filing may attract a penalty. citeturn9search5

## 4) How to get a “certified true copy” of your sole proprietor resolution/minutes
### Step 1 — Create the resolution/minutes (you draft it yourself)
Use something like this (copy/paste and edit):

```text
SOLE PROPRIETOR’S WRITTEN RESOLUTION
(Authorising DBS Bank Account Opening and Mandate)

Business Name: [YOUR REGISTERED BUSINESS NAME]
UEN: [YOUR UEN]
Date: [DD MMM YYYY]

I, [FULL NAME], NRIC [SXXXXXXX], being the sole proprietor of the above business, RESOLVE THAT:

1. Account Opening
   The Business is authorised to open and maintain account(s) with DBS Bank Ltd (“DBS”),
   including (as applicable) a DBS Business Multi-Currency Account and any related services.

2. Authorised Signatory / Mandate
   I, [FULL NAME], am appointed as the sole authorised signatory for the account(s).
   The signing mandate shall be: “Any 1 signatory to sign” (i.e., myself only).

3. Operating Authority
   DBS is authorised to act on all instructions, applications, and documents in relation to the
   account(s) when signed by me in accordance with the above mandate, including (as applicable)
   internet banking/DBS IDEAL set-up, account maintenance requests, and payment instructions.

Signed:

_____________________________
[YOUR FULL NAME]
Sole Proprietor
NRIC: [SXXXXXXX]
Date: [DD MMM YYYY]
```

### Step 2 — “Certified True Copy”: easiest is to let DBS do it
DBS’ checklist explains the rule:

- **Bring the original**, or  
- if you’re submitting a copy, it must be **certified true** by an external certifier (e.g., **solicitor/lawyer/notary public/professional accountant/auditor/chartered secretary** in a FATF member country) **or by DBS bank staff**. citeturn1view0  

It also specifies what the certification must include (this is what the certifier / bank staff should write/stamp):
- the words **“Certified True Copy”**
- certifier **name + signature**
- **occupation/title**
- **firm/company**
- **date**
- **country of practice**
- **professional registration/ID number** (where applicable). citeturn1view0

So the practical move is: **bring the original resolution/minutes to DBS**, and ask DBS staff to certify the photocopy after sighting the original. citeturn1view0
